publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Written by the late Rev. D. J. S. D. D. D. S. P. D.
AS youthful Strephon, t'other day,
Walk'd with a friend, along the quay,
A lovely nymph, the shepherd saw,
In whom they cou'd not find a flaw;
Her winning form, and graceful parts:
Too soon transfix'd their tender hearts:
Oh! she was fair, divinely fair!
Had jet-black eyes, and flowing hair,
Which down her back in ringlets play'd,
And dignify'd, the comely maid.But words, alas! are poor and vain
To paint the younger shepherd's pain,
As down a lane the goddess flew,
And seem'd to take her last adieu.
But Strephon, wise as he was young,
Follow'd her close, and held his tongue,
Till at her friend's she safe arrived;
A loss too great to be survived!
Trembling he found the door on jar,
And saw his fond love-leading star:
But, oh! most sad and dismal case!
Men are ne'er seen come near this place;
Therefore, Miss bid him change his station,
To save her half-lost reputation.
Who can imagine Strephon's plight
When miss was call'd from the first flight,
With shrilling accents of a shrew?
“What noise is that?──Come up here you:
“You have some fellow with you sure;
“Come up, I say, and shut the door.”
The trembling lad was much confused
To hear the fair one so abused
(Whose real merit's right to praise
Demands a nobler poets lays,)
On his account. With down-cast look
Behind the door his station took:
Sucking his cheeks, he silent stood
As lifeless as a piece of wood.
He view'd the charmer of his soul;
And cou'd not his address controul:
“Oh lovely beauteous fair, said he,
“Who wou'd not suffer much for thee?
“Who wou'd not bear an age of pain
“A single smile from you to gain?
“Or freely give up life and land
“For one soft kiss of thy fair hand?
“But I'm constrain'd to leave behind
“The dearest treasure of my mind:
“Yet one kind kiss before we part.”
At this the nymph let such a F──T
As made the very cellar ring,
Bottles and glasses all to sing.
The modest youth his silence broke,
(Being with laughter like to choak.)
Again the lady call'd above;
Again the youth address'd his love;
Again, again did Caelia f--t,
And quite set free the shepherd's heart;
Nor can the force of time or art
Efface the memory of the F──T.
